Posts.Content: Join us starting at 11 a.m. ET on Monday for a live chat hosted by NPR political blogger Frank James. We'll be chatting about the inaugural events and the challenges President Obama faces in his second term.

Join us starting at 11 a.m. ET on Monday for a live chat hosted by NPR political blogger Frank James. We'll be chatting about the inaugural events and the challenges President Obama faces in his second term.
Submit your questions now for our live Inauguration Day chat. Frank James of NPR's It's All Politics blog will host. Our first guest is NPR's Nina Totenberg.
Submit your questions now for our live Inauguration Day chat. Frank James of NPR's It's All Politics blog will host. Our first guest is NPR's Nina Totenberg.

Welcome to NPR.org’s live-chat coverage of President Obama’s second inaugural. And a happy Martin Luther King Jr. holiday to everyone.

It’s a brisk, sunny day in the nation’s capital for this, the 57th presidential inauguration.

Welcome to NPR.org’s live-chat coverage of President Obama’s second inaugural. And a happy Martin Luther King Jr. holiday to everyone.

It’s a brisk, sunny day in the nation’s capital for this, the 57th presidential inauguration.
@NPRinskeep @nprAudie @arishapiro on the air with live coverage of #inaug2013 from @nprnews w/director @sarahhandel pbs.twimg.com/media/BBJKAUyCMAALFs2.jpg
@NPRinskeep @nprAudie @arishapiro on the air with live coverage of #inaug2013 from @nprnews w/director @sarahhandel pbs.twimg.com/media/BBJKAUyCMAALFs2.jpg

We will be joined today at 11 am by NPR’s one and only Nina Totenberg, our Supreme Court correspondent extraordinaire, who will chat with us about the high court’s historic role in the ceremonies generally and Chief Justice John Roberts’ role in particular in the most recent presidential inaugurations.

We will be joined today at 11 am by NPR’s one and only Nina Totenberg, our Supreme Court correspondent extraordinaire, who will chat with us about the high court’s historic role in the ceremonies generally and Chief Justice John Roberts’ role in particular in the most recent presidential inaugurations.

Later, we will be joined by other NPR colleagues Justine Kenin and Becky Lettenberger
who will chat with us about their “Dear Mr. President” project, in which they asked everyday people what they would request President Obama do during his second term. We’ll ask Justine and Becky about the responses they thought were especially interesting.

Later, we will be joined by other NPR colleagues Justine Kenin and Becky Lettenberger
who will chat with us about their “Dear Mr. President” project, in which they asked everyday people what they would request President Obama do during his second term. We’ll ask Justine and Becky about the responses they thought were especially interesting.

Professor Matthew Green of Catholic University, a political scientist and congressional expert will also join us. He wrote a very useful book called “The Speaker of the House.” He’ll talk with us about relations between the president and Congress, particularly Speaker John Boehner.

Professor Matthew Green of Catholic University, a political scientist and congressional expert will also join us. He wrote a very useful book called “The Speaker of the House.” He’ll talk with us about relations between the president and Congress, particularly Speaker John Boehner.

Will be curious to see how today compares with four years ago both in style and substance.  I was there four years ago with my daughter and the crush of people was overwhelming.  We got separated at one point only to be reunited about an hour and half later with the help of my wife back in Indiana texting us separately since local cell service collapsed.  Thanks to the crowd I was in that decided to bypass the security check point and overturn a concrete barricade and the help of DC police I was able to reunite with my daughter and we got to see the inauguration.  It was an incredible experience.  The buzz in the air and the energy in the crowd was amazing.  Curious to see what your impressions are.  And oh yes, Nina, did Adult Protective Services ever come over to check on your husband's well being after his appearance on Wait Wait!

I'm honored and grateful that we have a chance to finish what we started. Our work begins today. Let's go. -bo
I'm honored and grateful that we have a chance to finish what we started. Our work begins today. Let's go. -bo

@DougMulvaney: I will let Nina answer the question about her husband's well-being. But in terms of the crowd experience, there are a few differences this time from last. Because of the problems with cell service in 2009, officials have added more mobile cell towers than they had last time. Even so, someone I know who's in the crowd at the Capitol tells me she's having problems getting a cell signal. There are also many more official helpers out to direct ticketholders etc to the right entry gates. We have NPR people out in the crowd and we're hoping to hear from them what the mood is like and have them describe what they're seeing.

So Nina, how many of these inaugurals have you covered or attended?
So Nina, how many of these inaugurals have you covered or attended?

@MarkaJohannes: I do not know that they are as a rule that long. The longest speech given was by William Henry Harrison in 1841. He delivered that speech (almost 2 hours, and 8,444 words) in the rain and in the cold without a coat, and died 30 days later from pneumonia. President Obama's speech last time was 2,395 words. The Wall Street Journal has a neat comparison tool for all of the Inaugural addresses: graphics.wsj.com.

the first one I remember is Reagan.  I used to do pieces about picking a gown.  that way I would go to the fanciest shops in town, with a producer, and try on dresses I couldn't afford.  One year I used Bob Edwards as my judge of dresses.  unfortunately, our listeners occasionally thought I was using npr money to BUY these gowns.  Alas, I only wore them for a few minutes in the store.

in the   supreme court trivia dept, all spouses of supreme court justices are invited to sit on the platform. I am told that Cathy Stone, the widow of Justice William O. Douglas, is there with her husband James Stone.  Douglas died in 1975 and  his widow remarried.

Nina, how much was Chief Justice John Roberts personally affected by the brouhaha over the flub of the 2009 swearing in? He seems like such a straight-laced guy. He almost comes across as a perfectionist. What's the inside dope on how he reacted back then?

Nina, how much was Chief Justice John Roberts personally affected by the brouhaha over the flub of the 2009 swearing in? He seems like such a straight-laced guy. He almost comes across as a perfectionist. What's the inside dope on how he reacted back then?
knowing Chief Justice Roberts as I don't.........by that I mean, I have known him literally for decades,  and he is a cordial, gracious, and incredibly smart man.....but self revelatory?  No way.
knowing Chief Justice Roberts as I don't.........by that I mean, I have known him literally for decades,  and he is a cordial, gracious, and incredibly smart man.....but self revelatory?  No way.
Which brouhaha are you referring to, Frank? I remember the State of the Union flub, but I'm fuzzy on the inauguration flub.
Which brouhaha are you referring to, Frank? I remember the State of the Union flub, but I'm fuzzy on the inauguration flub.

A tweet from Michelle Obama:

Honored and blessed to be joining so many of my fellow Americans gathered to watch the Inauguration. –mo

@Isaac: www.npr.org - Nina's story for context.
@Isaac: www.npr.org - Nina's story for context.

He is a perfectionist, and memorized the oath last time. Memorizing was part of his prep school education. But.....last time things went awry because the e mail he sent twice, indicating where he would pause, never got to the Obama staff, leading to some confusion during the oath. and cool as the chief is, he had never been before 2 million people before, and had not brought a copy of the oath with him. We don't know for sure whether he will bring one this time, but he seemed to have a paper with him at the White House Yesterday.

Nina, if  the words "So help me God" aren't prescribed by the Constitution, then why doesn't the addition of it make the oath invalid? Has there been any legal discussion of this? If there was concern that the transposing of a few words made the 2009 oath invalid, why doesn't the addition of "So help me God" make it invalid?

If there was concern that the transposing of a few words made the 2009 oath invalid, why doesn't the addition of "So help me God" make it invalid?

Thanks to the flub by Chief Justice Roberts, President Obama's four swearing in ceremonies will become trivia fodder for Ken Rudin some day. I heard that the two of them have a complete copy of the oath this time that they have been reviewing.

@Doug: We'll have to flag it for him!
@Doug: We'll have to flag it for him!

I don't think it matters what a President says before or after the oath, as long as he says the oath. And past presidents have often flubbed the oath, it appears.  When Chief Justiced William Howard Taft swore in Herbert Hoover in 1929, he substituted an important word, and when it was called to his attention later, he replief, in effect, "oh before radio we did much worse things than that."

BHO walks under arch, into sunlight, looks at crowd.  First audible word: "hey!"

As to "so help me God," for a long time, it was just assumed that every President back to Washington had said those words,  But according to Yale law professor Akhil Amar, who has studied this extensively, Washington probably didn't say those words.  The notion that he did was popularized by writer Washington Irving,  who claimed to have attended the inaugruation at age 6 and to have heard George Washington say those words.  Irving wrote all about it decades later in a Washington biography.  But it turns out that none of the very detailed contemporaneous accounts mentioned this fact. they did mention that washington kissed the bible, but not that he said,, "so help me God."    More to the point, Irving was a famous fabulist--he made things up all the time.  not to mention the fact that one wonders how a six your old kid would remember words, or even hear them when he was standing more than 100 yards away in an era of no microphones.
Nina, so the chief justice always administers the oath to the president. But what about the vice president?
the vice president picked sotomayor to do the duties this year.
Nina, thanks so much for joining us.

Here's a trivia question: In which state has a president NOT been sworn in?
a) Vermont
b) New York
c) Texas
d) Virginia
Sen. Charles Schumer D-NY opens the ceremony by saying that the theme of the inauguration is "faith in America's future"

In which state has a president NOT been sworn in?

The correct answer is Virginia.

The first inauguration was in New York City.

While most swearing-ins have been in Washington, D.C., eight times the vice president took the oath of office as chief executive after the death of a president. Several of those were in other states.

On Aug. 23, 1923, Calvin Coolidge was sworn in as president at his family's homestead in Plymouth, Vt., after the death of Warren Harding.

On Nov. 22, 1963, aboard Air Force One on the tarmac at Love Field in Dallas, Lyndon Johnson was sworn in after the assassination of John F. Kennedy.

This just occurred to me. This is the 16th  Presidential inauguration, 18th swearing in (LBJ after the Kennedy assassination and Gerald Ford after Nixon's resignation). I wish that I had greater recall of all these historic events. Unfortunately I seem to have lost the sense of the historic throughout my ordinary life in this extraordinary country!
You can get more inauguration trivia here, courtesy of NPR's Greg Henderson: www.npr.org
Watching live.  The amount of the President's gray hair is amazing.  This office really ages the President.
If you want to compare recent presidents at their first and second inaugurations, check out this gallery: www.npr.org
The first daughters look fabulous as does the first lady. Let's not pretend that fashion doesn't matter at this event.
@Halli: NPR's Linda Holmes wrote a nice piece on the fashion of this earlier: www.npr.org .
Myrlie Evers-Williams delivers invocation - "We come at this time to ask blessings on our leaders … on our armed forces … "
If you're wondering where President George W. Bush is, both he and his father, the first President Bush, are skipping today's event: www.usatoday.com
The National  Mall is full and closed for the inauguration of President Obama -- US Park Police DC.

NPR's Pam Fessler reports: "The National Park Service has just reported that the Mall is now full and closed.  Anyone else now is being told to go to overflow area at the Washington Monument." That message came at 11:35 a.m.
We're now joined by my NPR colleagues Becky Lettenberger and Justine Kenin who will talk with us about their "Dear Mr. President" project. Becky and Justine, thanks for joining us.
Brooklyn Tabernacle Choir now singing Battle Hymn of the Republic
Hello! Thanks for having us.
Wow--What a performance by the Brooklyn Tabernacle Choir!
Becky and Justine, so what did you hear from people who responded to the "Dear Mr. President" project? What were the key themes people kept hitting on?
This was a submission this morning to the Dear Mr. President project from the National Mall: inauguration2013.tumblr.com
Morning Frank and Becky

Also from the mall:

Janice Perez, 19-year-old from Connecticut wants to see better healthcare. #dearprez http://instagram.com/p/UwDwHBxIeG/
Thanks to Becky and Justine for creating and sharing the images and messages, even the inappropriate ones.
Justine and I went down to the White House and asked folks to finish the sentence "Dear Mr. President..." and tell us what they want President Obama to remember as he starts his second term.

A lot of the same themes that we heard in the election -- gay rights, the economy, veterans' rights.  And overall those who voted for him and those who didn't just want to leave the country in great shape for the generations coming up behind them.
Biden swearing in next.
Another example: Allison Matus from Babylon, NY wants the president remember his own 2006 words on fiscal responsibility. inauguration2013.tumblr.com
Thanks DougMulvany
Vice President Biden recently referred to himself as president. He may just been looking ahead to 2016..
One of things Becky and I were seeking to do was to make sure that the conversation started during the campaign was able to continue.
Biden swearing in by new justice.
Becky and Justine, would you share with us some particularly memorable comments?
James Taylor is my favorite! What a treat.
twitpic.com/bx5a7h Statuary hall where the 3000 calorie (unconfirmed on the calories) inaugural luncheon will take place later today.
The photo below from Tamara Keith: "Statuary hall where the 3000 calorie (unconfirmed on the calories) inaugural luncheon will take place later today."
My favorite was Ms. Murphy
She was so excited to be at the White House, and effusive with her congratulations to the president, but she didn't vote for him.
EXCELLENT self-control, there. I so would NOT have said "Oh, Foo" when the feed dropped.
The president is now taking the oath with Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts
Justice Roberts and President Obama have gotten plenty of practice repeating the oath. Practice makes perfect.
In a wonderfully gracious way she just said that if you don't have money, you don't spend it.
Ms. Murphy is highlighted in the video: www.npr.org
We also met Jacob Johnson, 16, from Brooklyn.  Jacob is a huge fan of President Obama.
Now all President Obama has to do is give a speech that ranks right up there with Lincoln's second inaugural.
inauguration2013.tumblr.com - Peter Olivo from West Hollywood CA wants us to focus on more technology.
I must say the inauguration2013.tumblr.com is super mesmerizing.
He was nearly speechless with joy to be at the White House and asked the president to remember education.
@Frank - no pressure haha!
Viveka from Berkeley wants @barackobama to remember Transparency - especially about the drone programs. inauguration2013.tumblr.com
her photo is great: inauguration2013.tumblr.com
Let us know what you want the president to remember in his second term. You can submit your answer here ( apps.npr.org ) or send us a comment in the chat.
Obama: "We learned that no union founded on the principles of liberty and equality could survive half-slave & half-free" #inaug2013
When Obama talks about the Founding Fathers not wanting to replace the tyranny of a king with the privileges of a few or mob rule, is he just stating history or making a comment about our time?
I enjoyed folks with a sense of humor like Alice Ladrick from South Bend, Ind. inauguration2013.tumblr.com
President Obama: "when times change, so must we"
The CSPAN feed just showed Sasha Obama yawning big time during her dad's big speech. We'll be seeing that juxtaposition again.

I love his comments about hard work and personal responsibility.  As a country, we need to get back to business, focus on improving education and infrastructure, and make responsible decisions--less arguing and more doing.
Reaction to Frank James: I think he is making a comment about our time. There does seem to be a theme here as I heard fragments in Shumer's and Alexander's remarks that bear that out.
A lot of folks want the president to remember soldiers, like Laura from Honolulu, HI, who has an adorable wedding photo inauguration2013.tumblr.com .
âThe commitments we make to each other ... do not sap our initiative; they strengthen our society.â
One interesting aspect of this speech is how the president is linking his agenda to "we the people" and thereby suggesting that those who oppose it are in opposition to "we the people."

To a Republican like me, this speech feels like a scolding from someone who is not thinking rationally.  Republicans don't oppose "science," and we don't propose to end Medicaid, Mdicare or Social Security.  We propose to make those things stronger through reform.
Tracy from San Francisco, CA modified this Vermeer and wants the {resident to remember women's equality. inauguration2013.tumblr.com.
The Washington Post's Capital Weather Gang reports the 40 degree temperature in Washington at noon is about 3 degrees above the average for January swearings-in: www.washingtonpost.com

All politicians make nice speeches, some better than others. It is the application that is important and how it effects our general population. Talk to the hundreds of nurses who are being laid off due to "Obamacare". Talk to the senior who can't buy medication now or the one on cancer medication. Talk to ordinary people who are suffering because their needs are now cut off.
A whole group of kids in Phoenix posted to the tumblr from what looks like their school's computer lab inauguration2013.tumblr.com
This speech has very strong echoes of Martin Luther King Jr. That's not surprising given today is the MLK holiday. Clearly, King was very much on Obama's mind as he wrote this speech.

Justine and Becky - I love the reminder what the "Dear Mr. President" project gives us - that we don't all agree, as evidenced by the submissions and by the chat we have here, but he is the president for everyone.
Anyone old enough, as I am, to remember the day Dr. King was assassinated must be staggered by this Inauguration.. as I am.
The mention of Stonewall is gutsy & significant. And followed by most explicit-almost-endorsement of same sex marriage.
Chris Miller from Honolulu, Hawaii wants the president to help reduce the impact money has on politics. He believes democracy depends on it. inauguration2013.tumblr.com
Kate -- I couldn't agree with you more.  And there was such a joy that came from the people we talked to in front of the White House -- no matter how they voted!
Thank you Thank you President Obama for acknowledging the climate change crisis!
And they loved just seeing the White House, and the Old Executive Office Building, and the Washington Monument all in one view.
sobering and moving speech
NPR's Greg Henderson was watching the clock -- he says Obama spoke for less than 20 minutes.
A special highlight for Becky and me was seeing Bo Obama have his midday walk.

Update at 12:08 p.m. ET from NPR's Mark Memmott:
He gets strong cheers for saying:
— "Our journey is not complete until our wives, our mothers, and daughters can earn a living equal to their efforts.
— "Our journey is not complete until our gay brothers and sisters are treated like anyone else under the law – for if we are truly created equal, then surely the love we commit to one another must be equal as well.
— "Our journey is not complete until no citizen is forced to wait for hours to exercise the right to vote.
— "Our journey is not complete until we find a better way to welcome the striving, hopeful immigrants who still see America as a land of opportunity; until bright young students and engineers are enlisted in our workforce rather than expelled from our country."
Here's a transcript of Obama's speech: www.npr.org
You can just make out Bo in this pic distilleryimage6.s3.amazonaws.com

More from Mark: In comments aimed at those who oppose his policies by questioning their constitutionality, the president says:

"Being true to our founding documents does not require us to agree on every contour of life; it does not mean we will all define liberty in exactly the same way, or follow the same precise path to happiness. Progress does not compel us to settle centuries-long debates about the role of government for all time – but it does require us to act in our time."
In the picture below, you can just make out First Dog, Bo Obama.

I'm still trying to decide what to make of the president's speech as I think many people are. It sounded like it was a call to action for Americans who agree with the president's agenda, to rally to his side. The White House has said it would try to carry the organizing and activism of the campaign into the next term and the speech seemed aimed at helping to do that.
Barack Obama has got to be sitting there watching Kelly Clarkson sing, thinking, "Didn't she endorse Ron Paul?" #inauguration #teamofrivals
Poet Richard Blanco is up now.

More highlights from Mark Memmott: "We possess all the qualities that this world without boundaries demands: youth and drive; diversity and openness; an endless capacity for risk and a gift for reinvention," says the president. "My fellow Americans, we are made for this moment, and we will seize it — so long as we seize it together."
Becky and Justine, thanks for joining us to talk about your "Dear Mr. President" project.
I heard in this speech an appeal to Americans to elevate the governance of our country above partisan tribalism through their more direct involvement.

The speech sounded like a call to action for supporters, but it also had some important validation of views from the conservative side of the spectrum:

"Through it all, we have never relinquished our skepticism of central authority, nor have we succumbed to the fiction that all society's ills can be cured through government alone. Our celebration of initiative and enterprise; our insistence on hard work and personal responsibility, are constants in our character."
If you would like to submit your own message to our Dear Mr. President, submissions are still open: see the "send your postcard" link at the top of this page.
Thanks for having us!
President Eisenhower gets lassoed at his inaugural parade in this AP photo. More funny photos here: www.npr.org
Thanks so much!  And please keep the postcards coming!  I love the vision of mail bags filling up.
The Poet Richard Blanco...finally a plain spoken poem that reminds us of the simple beauty of a day, a people, a life, a country.

@Missoulute: I agree with you that parts of the speech spoke to larger American values. So it wasn't a strictly partisan speech. But it will interesting to see more Republican response to the speech. Will it be seen as a unifying speech or a throwing down of the gantlet? I'm guessing more the latter.
I think he sounded angry and resolute. He wants to stop the all the baloney and make real change. It was definitely a challenge to those who oppose his efforts.
Luis Leon, Episcopal priest, delivers benediction. "bless us...that we may become a blessing among the nations of this world." #inauguration
Beyonce Knowles steps to the podium with tears in her eyes.

The president has long defined the role of government the way Lincoln defined it. That government's role is to do what individuals themselves can't do. It was a version of this that led to the "he didn't build that" comment of the campaign. This is what he said today:

"For the American people can no more meet the demands of today’s world by acting alone than American soldiers could have met the forces of fascism or communism with muskets and militias. No single person can train all the math and science teachers we’ll need to equip our children for the future, or build the roads and networks and research labs that will bring new jobs and businesses to our shores. Now, more than ever, we must do these things together, as one nation, and one people. "
This is the biggest Beyonce concert I've ever been too

Update to the liveblog at 12:30 p.m. ET.:

In his prayer, Dr. Luis León, pastor of St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington, D.C., asks God to bless the nation because it will "renew the ties of mutual regard which can best form our civic life." And with God's blessing, he says, "we will see we are created in your image" no matter what gender, race, sexual orientation or social status.
Beyonce has finished; the public ceremony is now wrapping up. The inaugural parade cranks up in a couple of hours.
We're joined by Gene Demby, NPR correspondent/blogger for our race, ethnicity and culture team. Gene, thanks for joining us.

@Frank James: I suspect Republicans will respond as though the speech was a gauntlet, but I think that reflects more strongly on our polarized, posturing-filled politics than it does the intent or tone of the speech.

Of course, after affirming those values Obama went on to state "when times change, so must we", so he definitely was advocating his own longstanding position of embracing change, which is by definition not conservative.
Thanks for having me, Frank!
Gene, what'd you think of the president's speech?
Here's the transcript for President Obama's address: http://www.npr.org/2013/01/21/169903155/transcript-barack-obamas-second-inaugural-address

Seneca Falls, Selma, Stonewall..."   I am so grateful to hear these places of struggle and emancipation and community, praised as signal moments in our shared history of freedom, in Barack Obama's inaugural addres

When Obama was running for his first term I thought he was all words and no action -- as in 'no backbone'. Over the years I have changed my views. He is genuine, compassionate and directed by a strong core. He is the 'velvet hammer'.

It was a common prediction among pundits that this speech would be a high-minded approach to commonality. And that he would devote the upcoming State of the Union address to hard-edged political argument.
If this wasn't hard-edged political argument, I don't know what is.
Jay-Z, Beyonce...and Paul Ryan all sharing the same space on the TV. Only at #inaug2013

@Frank: His speech was very pointed even as it weaved together some lofty ideas about Americans' obligations to each other. The president also folded the Stonewall riots into the history of rights movements of America --- a subtle but powerful statement.

From our liveblog: Update at 12:32 p.m. ET. On To Lunch, The Parade And The Balls:

With the ceremony now over, the action moves inside for a while. The Obamas and Bidens are due at a lunch with members of Congress. then, starting around 2:30 p.m. ET, there's the parade to the White House. And in the evening, two inaugural balls.
Our @NewsHour friends have video from today's ceremony: http://www.youtube.com/user/pbsnewshour
Gene, I absolutely agree with the noteworthiness of the Stonewall reference. Obama's mention is historic. I think it will be a signal moment in the gay rights movement.

Gene, I heard several echoes of King in the speech. At one point I thought it could even be a King speech. The following was very King like. Real echoes of King in 1963.

"Our journey is not complete until we find a better way to welcome the striving, hopeful immigrants who still see America as a land of opportunity; until bright young students and engineers are enlisted in our workforce rather than expelled from our country. Our journey is not complete until all our children, from the streets of Detroit to the hills of Appalachia to the quiet lanes of Newtown, know that they are cared for, and cherished, and always safe from harm."
Thank you Mr. President for your service. Now please, don't tell me show me. Much Love and Peace.
If you're enjoying lunch right now, you might appreciate this blog post about what they ate at President Lincoln's inaugural ball in 1865: www.npr.org

It's not so much the specifics that Obama referred to but the way he tied disparate groups and geographies together the way King did when he talked about  black children and white children, Jews and gentiles, linking hands and in the words of the old Negro spiritual singing "Free at Last" etc.

Frank: That passage definitely echoed King's speech at the March on Washington. But there were a lot of  references to 1963 --- an enormously consequential year for the Civil Rights Movement ---  even outside of the president's speech. Myrlie Evers-Williams gave the benediction; her husband, the civil rights leader Medgar Evers, was assassinated in 1963.
This speech represents who Obama really is and who he has wanted to be since he first began running for office.

From the liveblog: Update at 12:55 p.m. ET. The Timing Of That Presidential Tweet:

Picking up on one of the tidbits from earlier. The tweet from the president we noted says it was posted at 9:25 a.m. ET. According to the reporters who were in the "pool" that accompanied the Obama family to church this morning, the church service "was ending at 9:32 a.m."

Frank: That alliterative passage about those rights movements will be the most consequential, if not the most repeated.

"We, the people, declare today that the most evident of truths – that all of us are created equal – is the star that guides us still; just as it guided our forebears through Seneca Falls, and Selma, and Stonewall; just as it guided all those men and women, sung and unsung, who left footprints along this great Mall, to hear a preacher say that we cannot walk alone; to hear a King proclaim that our individual freedom is inextricably bound to the freedom of every soul on Earth."

But you're right: there doesn't seem to be a Kennedy-style exhortation toward service.

My vote for the most memorable line in the speech:
"For history tells us that while these truths may be self-evident, they have never been self-executing; that while freedom is a gift from God, it must be secured by His people here on Earth."

With a close second:
"Our journey is not complete until our gay brothers and sisters are treated like anyone else under the law — for if we are truly created equal, then surely the love we commit to one another must be equal as well."
Gene/Frank: Would you say the poet Blanco's imagry on 'hands working' sounds respect for service and working?

Here's a little color from our on-air broadcast: NPR's Scott Horsley says Obama's speech sounded similar to campaign rhetoric. "Today he talked about not only the votes we cast, but the voices we raise."
Winners of best inaugural hats prize, fm Augusta, GA. #npr #nprAtc pbs.twimg.com/media/BBJukPcCUAISkjv.jpg

My vote is for the big first  - "Our journey is not complete until our gay brothers and sisters are treated like anyone else under the law – for if we are truly created equal, then surely the love we commit to one another must be equal as well."

Jennifer from Salt Lake City wants us to remember that we are all Americans. http://inauguration2013.tumblr.com/post/41117537067/dear-mr-president-i-didnt-vote-for-you-i-know-i#posts pbs.twimg.com/media/BBJwc2BCAAA1H7S.jpg

Gene: Obama was definitely speaking to the ages today. One could argue that if coastal cities around the world are constantly inundated 100 years from now, people can look at the speech and say, "well at least Obama talked in his second inaugural about dealing with climate change." He said:

"We, the people, still believe that our obligations as Americans are not just to ourselves, but to all posterity. We will respond to the threat of climate change, knowing that the failure to do so would betray our children and future generations. Some may still deny the overwhelming judgment of science, but none can avoid the devastating impact of raging fires, and crippling drought, and more powerful storms. The path towards sustainable energy sources will be long and sometimes difficult. But America cannot resist this transition; we must lead it. We cannot cede to other nations the technology that will power new jobs and new industries – we must claim its promise. That is how we will maintain our economic vitality and our national treasure – our forests and waterways; our croplands and snowcapped peaks. That is how we will preserve our planet, commanded to our care by God. That’s what will lend meaning to the creed our fathers once declared. "
The food being served at the post-inaugural congressional lunch is bison.  This tradition dates back to 1976 -- the bisontennial.
Someone send Ken to AZ with his sense of Yuma.
Today's inaugural luncheon menu: bites.today.com .

BCarletonAZ: Very much so. And very much so about the many kinds of work that Americans engage in.

"Our ground, rooting us to every stalk of corn, every head of wheat sown by sweat
and hands, hands gleaning coal or planting windmills in deserts and hilltops that keep us warm, hands digging trenches, routing pipes and cables, hands as worn as my father’s cutting sugarcane
so my brother and I could have books and shoes."
Beyonce: Best presentation of the National Anthem I've ever heard. Well done.
Gene, thanks for sharing your great observations with us. Enjoy the rest of the day.
Hello, all. It seems the president made it clear to congressional Republicans that the second term would be very different, compared to his outreach efforts at the start of his first term.
Shirish, good to see you. Shirish is a Washington desk editor.
Shirish, extending that thought. What was Obama signaling? And did he give us an outline of his second term agenda?
Thanks for having me! I look forward to more insights from you and the readers.

Perhaps not so much an outline as a wish list. Climate change seems a big reach, given how many red state Democratic senators are up for re-election in 2014. Gay marriage is really in the hands of the U.S. Supreme Court and the states, it seems. Even gun control will be tough -- at least to the extent that many proponents would like. So this seemed an acknowledgment and thanks to his base.

Shirish, and perhaps also an opportunity to shape his legacy as a president who had some big achievements and big aspirations for the nation, who did what he could despite the limits set by his congressional opposition?
Interesting that conservative columnist Charles Krauthammer gives the speech rave reviews on Fox News.
Shirish, Krauthammer's response is interesting. Wonder how widespread that will be?

More from "Dear Mr. President" - Melanie Swenson from Provo, Utah believes that Equality Is ‘The Star That Guides Us Still’.
inauguration2013.tumblr.com
Shirish, if Krauthammer is any guide, maybe the conservative response to the speech won't be as negative to the speech as I initially thought.
Not that Mr. Krauthammer was agreeing with the policies the president advocated. I think it was more of a positive critique of the speech as a rhetorical device.
Shirish, how would you compare this speech to the president's first inaugural speech?

Congressional opposition that Obama perhaps didn't anticipate would be as vociferous as it was back in 2009. Recall, he seemed to reach out more to Republicans four years ago, looking for a bipartisan compromise, than he did to fellow Democrats.
The president took a little more time leaving the stage and said, "I'm not going to see this again." www.youtube.com

Shirish, what's also interesting about this speech is that it shows how far we've come since the financial crisis of 2009. That first inaugural was very focused on the economic crisis at hand and how to get out of it. This speech was much more wide ranging.

Obama this time is a guy who knows exactly what he's up against, and that the niceties of today's ceremony notwithstanding, he will need to fight for every inch he wins -- and is not going to waste a national platform like the inaugural on kumbaya platitudes.

Michael Beschloss on Morning Edition today was right and wrong. Right because president’s ‘Second Terms Are Historically Hard To Navigate”, wrong because not health care but climate will be Obama’s signature legislation and legacy.

1.1 Million #Inauguration -related Tweets during #Inaug2013 ceremony. Total for 2009 = ~82k.

Erica, good question. I would say that the second inaugurals during my years as a journalist, dating back to Reagan in 1985, have had less energy than the first. I think that's inevitable because a president entering a second term is too familiar by the point of his second inaugural to have that aura of excitement. The strongest feeling many people have after second inaugurals is: "Is that all there is?"
On Mall working a story for tonight's @npratc with @ailsachang. We're being serenaded to music that sounds a lot like the Star Wars Theme
An inauguration photo gallery from the Chicago Tribune. Here's one of first lady Michelle Obama cheering Beyoncé after her performance. galleries.apps.chicagotribune.com

@Fairfax Jo: I doubt if climate change legislation is going to be a bigger Obama legacy than health care. First, with the current Congress, he's not going to get climate legislation. It took the stars being aligned during his first term -- Democrats holding the House and Senate -- for health care's passage. And it largely happened because then-Speaker Nancy Pelosi is one of the best arm twisters and vote counters on Capitol Hill.  If Obama has a legacy on climate, it will be that he made incremental progress, higher fuel-efficiency standards as part of the auto bailout, for instance, and investments that were made as part of the 2009 economic stimulus.

By the way – just as the inauguration festivities were getting underway, House Republicans announced they will vote Wednesday on their plan to put off the debt ceiling fight until May 19, but tie that to a requirement that Congress pass a budget by April 15. (The Senate has not passed a budget in years.) Members of a chamber that failed to pass a budget would have their paychecks withheld. So, truce over, and let the game continue where we left off.
Here's both video and full text of @rblancopoet delivering his inaugural words http://www.npr.org/blogs/thetwo-way/2013/01/21/169905447/watch-one-today-an-inaugural-poem

Glad to be here!
Matt, so what did you make of the president's speech today? I'm especially interested in knowing what you think it will do for his relationship with congressional Republicans.

Gray (cont. into ) …. what it means for the people in DC.  While we must be created equal, we are not treated equal in DC." (2/2)

I thought the speech was an interesting mix of broad rhetoric and particular policy goals.  When the president talked about things like climate change, health care, and school reform, there were hints of a state of the union address.  Frankly, I don't think the speech will change much about his relationship with Republicans on the Hill, most of whom disagree pretty fundamentally with Obama's agenda.

Matt, good point on the speech sounding something like a State of the Union. How much of the speech was meant for his legacy, a document he wants the future to read and say "Well, at least he cared about the right things?"
Last inaug: Aretha Franklin, b 1942 into segregation. This one: Beyonce, b 1981 into a different America. Part of the journey we mark today.

Here's some reaction to the speech:

WASHINGTON - House Republican Conference Chair Cathy McMorris Rodgers (R-WA) today issued the following statement on the occasion of President Obama’s second inauguration:

“House Republicans are eager to be responsible partners with the President during his second-term, working together to create new jobs at home and greater security abroad.

“Yet, the President’s eloquent words must be matched with deliberate actions to restore country’s fiscal health. In his Inaugural Address today, he said: “We must make the hard choices to reduce the cost of health care and the size of our deficit. ” Yet, it is almost four years since the Senate passed a budget. In the meantime, spending has raged out of control and America’s debt has ballooned.

“The Senate must act now to turn words into deeds. Senate Democrats must pass a budget putting federal spending on a sustainable path to ensure a successful second term and for the sake of our children and grandchildren.”
Awaiting the start of the parade. And clearly we're next to the Canadian embassy #inauguration #inaug2013 pbs.twimg.com/media/BBJ-JNWCEAAdKAX.jpg

Matt, the statement we posted a little while ago from Rep. McMorris-Rodgers, a member of the House GOP leadership, pretty much underscores your point that not much is likely to change in the relationship between Obama and congressional Republicans.

Yes, Rep. McMorris-Rodgers' statement didn't surprise me very much.
In answer to your previous question: second term presidents do generally think about their legacy even more than first term ones. And some of Obama's rhetoric may well be aimed at establishing that legacy. (I'm thinking in particular his references to equality, gay rights, and communal action.) But I should expect Obama is aware that legacies are decided largely by what follows that speech -- what a president's second term is actually like. By making references to specific (largely liberal) policy proposals, Obama may have been thinking more about appealing to his party and left-leaning voters. (And maybe the audience on the Mall today.)
Producer Sam Sanders staying warm instagr.am/p/UwdmGTOEj6/

Matt, so is there any major legislation you see Obama and congressional Republicans able to agree on? I assume congressional Republicans will want to have some significant legislation the president will sign into law so Congress can look effective. Or is saying no to Obama enough.
A pup named Juicy braved the cold and crowd to attend President Obama's inauguration ceremony. (@johnwpoole/NPR) http://instagram.com/p/UwSB7TuI83/

I think Obama and congressional Republicans will likely find some common ground on an immigration reform bill.  The G.O.P. is too worried about losing the Latino vote in future elections to let that opportunity go.  And I hope that both parties will at least agree that we can't shut down the government or default on our debt.  But other than that, it's hard to think what else the two sides can agree on at this point.
Keep in mind, too, that Congress does pass smaller bills that Obama might agree to -- not everything will be gridlock in the 113th congress.

"I want to take a look," he could be heard saying, because "I'm not going to see this again." www.npr.org

<object width="640" height="390"><param name="movie" value="//www.youtube.com/v/ZFOoqX8kJTs" /><param name="wmode" value="Transparent" /><embed src="//www.youtube.com/v/ZFOoqX8kJTs" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" wmode="Transparent" width="640" height="390" /></object>

No, it's not overstating things at all. A president doesn't have to have his signature on a hundred major bills to leave a lasting legacy. If all that Reagan had done in his 2nd term was sign tax reform into law, he'd still be known for a productive four years.

What I think Obama needs to worry about is the unexpected snafus, crises, and mistakes that tend to plague second-term presidents.  These can cause as much trouble for presidents as anything.  And they're often self-inflicted mistakes, too.

Here I am...
Hey Julie. So what was the highlight from the day from your perspective?
The hats of Sen. Majority Leader Harry Reid and his wife Landra. instagr.am/p/UwfbomNeDP/

Wow. I think I'm getting a little jaded. This is my 9th inauguration, if you count the ones my parents took me to as a toddler. I still love the ceremony, though, and how excited the people are who come. Democrats and Republicans. It's a great piece of America.
You can't be a true Washington journalist without being a little jaded.
I still love election night more. There's not a lot of adrenaline that comes with Inauguration day. It's a little like covering someone else's prom.

Julie, the president is at the congressional lunch right now. I remember that four years ago Ted Kennedy was at that lunch. And he had some health issue there. Of course, Kennedy is gone. But, in a way, his legacy lives on in the health care legislation. Didn't he make Obama promise, back when Obama was a candidate in 2007, that Obama would tackle health care?
I have a theory that the reason Kennedy gave Obama Bo was so that the dog would be a constant reminder to Obama of the health care promise.

Yes, that was very moving. And I think it's at least part of the reason Obama went ahead and pursued the health law, even though many of his advisers didn't want him to. Kennedy died before the bill became law.
How do you get picked to bake the inaugural cake? http://www.npr.org/blogs/thesalt/2013/01/21/169854456/the-ace-of-cakes-next-challenge-the-inaugural-ball-cake

And actually I think there was some negotiating about Bo...but he is a living legacy of the relationship between Kennedy and Obama. Remember it was a huge deal when Kennedy endorsed Obama in 2008 rather than Hillary Clinton.
The thing about inaugurals is that they are a lot like other Washington set piece events. We in the news media hype them so much that it's hard for them to live up to their advance billing.
I wish bipartisanship could exist beyond lunch and speeches.
Another thing is that they NEVER run on time. They are still in the lunch, even tho the parade was supposed to have started already, I believe.
Yes, they are running about 15 minutes late. Which is not fun if you're one of the many many people standing out in the cold.

This Maryland family is keeping warm as they wait for the inaugural parade to begin. Catch it live at 2:35 p.m. pbs.twimg.com/media/BBJsTbGCcAAotaD.jpg

Unfortunately the parade is running late.
Do we know how long this parade is supposed to last? I always feel bad for the marchers at the end because it's usually dark and cold and the reviewing stands have usually emptied out by then.

The timeline I have only goes to the start of the parade...I'm sure I have another one someplace, but you're right, it's always dark by the time the last few marchers come by, and only stragglers left on the street to watch. There are, however, usually people watching from warm office buildings above.
Probably the biggest item of suspense in the parade is, will the president and first lady leave the Beast, as the presidential limo is called, and, if so, where?

Aboslutely. I heard on my way in this am that last time they got out around 7th street. But I'm not sure that's any sort of clue. I think the betting, however, is heavy that they will get out and walk at some point. And BTW, parade supposed to end at 5:30 pm.

Sounds like the Washington DC sanitation department is going to have its hands full. Which reminds me of a poem I heard today...
President and First Lady walked through Capitol Rotunda to visit statue of Martin Luther King on their way to the motorcade...

The political climate in our country is so polarized. We have ideologues on both sides who are unwilling to budge and thus we are at a standstill. I think American needs to learn how to compromise, which, being a twin, is concept I've been intimately aware of since childhood. My mom would always tell me that neither side is fully satisfied in a compromise, but each party does get something they want. Politicians need to remember that.
A fitting end to the lunch on MLK day. Julie, thanks for joining the live chat today. We really appreciate it.
my pleasure

Congressional gridlock begs the question if there should be a new legal mechanism allow one branch of government to force the hand of in answering a question?  Congress has been unable to provide budget solutions that gel with the will of the people - why would they be able to do so for climate change or guns if not forced?
We've come to the end of NPR's live-chat coverage of President Obama's second inaugural. Thanks for spending it with us.
